Added support for Trusted Types.

DOMPurify detects if TrustedTypes are available. If so, will create an inner no-op policy, with a name 'dompurify', optionally suffixed with a value specified in a data-tt-policy-suffix attribute of the script using DOMPurify. It will use that policy when interacting with the (dirty) DOM, and will return a TrustedHTML object instead of a string.

See https://github.com/WICG/trusted-types.

Merge pull request #303 from mikesamuel/make-everything-harder

Hardened to resist interference by naive code in other modules.

Hardened to resist interference by naive code in other modules.

This doesn't make it impossible to pull the rug out from under
purify code, but does mean that it preserves semantics in the face
of naive code that does the equivalent of

*  import(a)[b] = c where (a, b, c) are attacker controlled strings
*  Builtin.prototype.newProperty = polyfill

This does not atempt the much larger number of dependencies on builtin
prototypes like String.prototype.match or Array.prototype.push.

So if an application makes existing properties on the builtin prototypes
non-configurable and loads purify early then purify should preserve
semantics.

----

Specific changes include:

*  Modifies util.js addToSet to separate "set" objects from Object.prototype
*  Modifies util.js addToSet to not reassign to arrays when no change is
   needed so we can freeze whitelists like those in attrs.js and tags.js
*  Seals RegExps in regexp.js so that we can rely on their test and exec
   methods being the ones defined on RegExp.prototype.
*  Throughout, grab static methods like Object.freeze early instead of
   relying on polyfills not to overly aggressively replace them.
*  Throughout, prefers Reflect.apply to Function.prototype.{call,apply}
   which can be masked.

Merge pull request #166 from neilj/attr-security-flaw

Attr security flaw

Fix "forbidden" attributes allowed if ALLOW_UNKNOWN_PROTOCOLS true

The logic for whether to forbid an attribute was broken: if
ALLOW_UNKNOWN_PROTOCOLS was true, then it would allow any attribute with
a value that didn't match the IS_SCRIPT_OR_DATA regexp.

This evades the attribute name whitelist, and is a security flaw: for
example you could set an "onX" JavaScript attribute.

The logic here got too convoluted to be easy to read, which is
presumably how this bug crept in. I have rewritten it into an expanded
set of if/else statements which I believe are easier to follow.

Merge pull request #78 from fastmail/contentblacklist

Change CONTENT_TAGS to blacklist

Change CONTENT_TAGS to blacklist

Previously, if you use the KEEP_CONTENT option, the tag had to match a
whitelist for its contents to be kept. This is not necessary for security,
since the contents is still sanitised just like any other content in the page,
and is annoying if you are sanitising random HTML from sources which may use
arbitrary non-standard tags to wrap bits of real content (resulting in chunks
of text being stripped by the sanitiser).

This commit changes the CONTENT_TAGS whitelist to a FORBID_CONTENTS blacklist;
the blacklist is not needed for security, but we do want to remove the contents
of <script> tags, style tags (if <style> has been disallowed) and anything in
the <head> (if disallowed), since we know these are not designed to have
user-visible content.

Implements #65.

Merge pull request #64 from fastmail/clobber

Update _isClobbered to check currently required properties

Update _isClobbered to check currently required properties

The _isClobbered fn detects whether any of the methods/attributes we need on
the element have been clobbered. The properties it checks for had not been
updated with the changes in how the sanitisation methods manipulated the
elements, meaning it was making some unnecessary checks, and not making some
required ones, which could result in an error being thrown with certain input.

Merge pull request #57 from fastmail/allowedtagattribute

Allow more benign contents/attributes

Allow background, cellpadding and cellspacing attributes

Although obsolete, this attributes are still commonly used in HTML emails and
are still supported by all current browsers. As they do not pose a security
risk, they should be in the default set of allowed attributes.

Preserve contents of <o:p> tag

The non-standard <o:p> tag is generated by MS Outlook in HTML emails it creates.
The tag is nonsense and can be stripped, but its contents must be preserved in
order to preserve the intended semantics of the document. (In particular, it
often holds significant white-space).

Merge pull request #54 from fastmail/attributes

Tidy, optimise & improve hook in _sanitizeAttributes

Tidy, optimise & improve hook in _sanitizeAttributes

* Tidies code, reordering a few things for more efficient execution, removing
  the need to clone the DOM node and caching values in local variables to
  reduce object lookup costs.
* Improves the uponSanitizeAttribute hook:
  - The hook is now called *before* removing the attribute from the node. This
    allows the hook to access any parsed version of the attribute available on
    the node (e.g. the "style" attribute).
* The hook no longer passes the attr object itself, since this contains no
  extra information beyond the name/value already in the hook data.
* The hook has a new "keepAttr" property, which may be set to `false` by the
  hook to reject the attribute even if it would otherwise be kept by the
  whitelist.
* The hook function may change the value to be set for the attribute by setting
  the attrValue property on the hook data object it is passed.
Added test before hook removal

Merge pull request #52 from fastmail/refine

Optimise and refine
Add test for presence of isSupported property.

Add regression test for RETURN_DOM with simple string.

Make sure the DOM node is returned even if the string has no "<" character.

Fix check for body/html node type in _initDocument

The check in _initDocument that the node is of the right type will always fail,
since the node will never be both an instance of HTMLBodyElement and
HTMLHtmlElement. Fix this to only check against the type we expect based on
WHOLE_DOCUMENT cofig, and tidy code to be a little easier to read.

Move internal methods/variables out of sanitize closure.

At the moment, they are re-evaluated on every call to DOMPurify#sanitize(),
which is unnecessarily work for subsequent calls.

Convert allowed tags/attr lists to lookup tables.

Calling Array#indexOf on the list for every node/attribute is expensive as this
is an O(n) operation. Much better to convert to an object first, then we can
lookup in O(1).

Add isSupported property to DOMPurify.

So library users can easily check if the browser supports sanitising properly.

Fix conditions for shortcut return from sanitize

* Should not shortcut if expecting a DOM object to be returned.
* Should not shortcut if expecting the whole document including <html> etc.
  to be returned.

Fix documentation of dirty param type in sanitize

The dirty parameter has to be a string. If it were an existing DOM node,
setting outerHTML will result in converting it to a string, which will be
something like `<body>[object HTMLDivElement]</body>`, not the contents of the
DOM node itself.

Move check for safe string out of _initDocument.

This means _initDocument now always returns a DOM node, rather than sometimes
a string, making it easier for compilers to optimise and for humans to
understand.

Remove DEBUG_OUTPUT option.

As it's entirely unused.

Remove pointless condition in keep content check.

It used to check for the presence of a currentNode.nodeName.toLowerCase
property. Not sure why, but this MUST always exist otherwise an error would
have been thrown at line 316 when currentNode.nodeName.toLowerCase() was called,
since currentNode has not been reassigned or significatnly changed since then.

Remove needless check for comment node type.

Unless "#comment" is added to the allowed types, it won't be kept anyway. And
if someone did want to keep comments, they could now add this to the allowed
tags list.

Optimise regular expressions

* Use regexp.test as it's faster for checking if there's a match.
* Use non-capturing group as capture not used.

Shallow clone node in _sanitizeAttributes

Deep cloning (cloning all children along with the node) is unnecessary as only
the attributes are being used. Shallow cloning is much less expensive.

Fix whitespace inconsistencies.

Merge pull request #3 from hyderali/master

Fixes bug in IE, where all attributes have empty value after sanitizing.

Fixes bug in IE, where all attributes have empty value after sanitizing.
In `_sanitizeAttributes`, the attribute is referenced in a variable
(`tmp`) and removed from `currentNode`.
In IE, after the attribute is removed from `currentNode`, the value in
`tmp` variable is also removed. So instead of just getting the attribute
from `currentNode`, clone `currentNode` and get the attribute from the
`clonedNode`.
